tit.e: Nittoboeki (trade between Japan and Tang dynasty China)
tit.cmt: Nittoboueki→Nittoboeki,カッコ内を修正しました。
tit.e: Nittoboeki (trade between Japan and Tang dynasty China)

sen.j: 日唐貿易（にっとうぼうえき）とは、日本と唐の間で行われた貿易関係のこと。
sen.e: Nittoboueki (日唐貿易) is the trade that was carried on between Japan and Tang dynasty China.
Nittoboeki (日唐貿易) is the trade that was carried on between Japan and Tang dynasty China.
Nittoboeki (日唐貿易) is the trade that was carried on between Japan and Tang dynasty China.

sen.j: この時代の貿易は遣唐使に付随して行われる朝貢貿易（朝貢に対する回賜・購入）が主であったが、必ずしも民間の交易船が存在しなかったことを意味するものではない。
sen.e: Although The trading at that time was mainly the tribute trade along with the dispatch of Japanese envoy to the Tang Dynasty China, it does not mean that there were no private trading ships.

Although the trading at that time was mainly the tribute trade (tribute, and gift returns, purchases to conform it) along with the dispatch of Japanese envoy to the Tang Dynasty China, it does not mean that there were no private trading ships.
sen.cmt: The→the と修正しました。カッコ部分を補いました。
sen.e: Although the trading at that time was mainly the tribute trade (tribute, and gift returns, purchases to conform it) along with the dispatch of Japanese envoy to the Tang Dynasty China, it does not mean that there were no private trading ships.

sen.j: 例えば、養老令の関市令には外蕃に対する無条件の国家による先買権の存在が記されている。
sen.e: For instance, there is a definition about the nation's right of preemption in the trading between Japan and gaiban (外蕃) (derogatory expression of foreign countries and foreigners) in Genshi Ryo (関市令) (regulations of markets and checking stations) of Yoro-ryo (養老令) (Yoro Code).

For instance, there is a definition about the nation's right of preemption in the trading between Japan and gaiban (derogatory expression of foreign countries and foreigners) in Genshi Ryo (regulations of markets and checking stations) of Yoro-ryo (Yoro Code).
sen.cmt: 漢字のカッコ部分を削除しました。スペースを修正しました。
sen.e: For instance, there is a definition about the nation's right of preemption in the trading between Japan and gaiban (derogatory expression of foreign countries and foreigners) in Genshi Ryo (regulations of markets and checking stations) of Yoro-ryo (Yoro Code).

sen.j: 遅くても奈良時代後期には民間による貿易関係は成立していたとされ、新羅・渤海国などを中継した貿易関係も存在したと考えられている。
sen.e: It is said that the private trade relationship came into existence in the late Nara period at the latest, and also the trade relationship that relayed Shiragi (新羅) (ancient Korean kingdom) and Bo Hai (渤海国) seems to be existed.

It is said that the private trade relationship came to exist in the late Nara period at the latest, and also the trade relationship that relayed Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) and Bo Hai seems to have existed.
sen.cmt: into existence→to exist, be→have と修正しました。漢字のカッコ部分を削除しました。
sen.e: It is said that the private trade relationship came to exist in the late Nara period at the latest, and also the trade relationship that relayed Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) and Bo Hai seems to have existed.

sen.j: 歴史上において、円仁の入唐求法を助けた新羅商人張保皐・金珍の存在が知られた。
sen.e: The existence of the Shiragi merchant, Jang Bogo (張保皐) and 金珍, who helped Ennin (円仁) trying to do Nitto Guho (travelling the Tang for seeking the teaching of Buddhism), was discovered.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対象張金珍←読み方不明
sen.e: The existence of these Shiragi merchants, Jang Bogo and 金珍, who helped Ennin trying to do Nitto Guho (travelling the Tang for seeking the teaching of Buddhism), was known in history.
sen.cmt: the→these,merchant→merchants,漢字のカッコ部分を削除しました。was discovered→was known in history と修正しました。 「金珍」の読みは確認できておりません。
sen.e: The existence of these Shiragi merchants, Jang Bogo and 金珍, who helped Ennin trying to do Nitto Guho (travelling the Tang for seeking the teaching of Buddhism), was known in history.

sen.j: 彼らは日本・新羅・唐の三国間交易に従事していた。
sen.e: They engaged in the trade among Japan, Shiragi and Tang.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対象
sen.e: They engaged in the trade between Japan, Shiragi and Tang.
They engaged in the trade between Japan, Shiragi and Tang.

sen.j: また、菅原道真が遣唐使廃止について上奏した「請令諸公卿議定遣唐使進止状」（『菅家文章』）にも在唐中の僧侶が唐の商人に道真への手紙を託したことが記されている。
sen.e: An episode that a monk in Tang sent a letter addressed to Michizane by a Shiragi merchant, is also written in the proposal for stopping Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China (請令諸公卿議定遣唐使進止状) (Kanke bunso (菅家文章) (an anthology of Chinese-style poetry by SUGAWARA no Michizane)) that reported to the Imperial Court by SUGAWARA no Michizane.
sen.cmt: 請令諸公卿議定遣唐使進止状 ←読み方不明
sen.e: An episode that a monk in Tang sent a letter addressed to Michizane by a Shiragi merchant, has been also written in the proposal for stopping Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China ("Kanke bunso" [an anthology of Chinese-style poetry by SUGAWARA no Michizane]) that reported to the Imperial Court by SUGAWARA no Michizane.
sen.cmt: カッコ内のカッコを修正しました。is→has been と修正しました。 クォーツを補いました。「請令諸公卿議定遣唐使進止状」の読み方は確認できておりません。ただ、ここでは漢字の表記は必要ないと思われ、漢字のカッコ部分は削除しました。
sen.e: An episode that a monk in Tang sent a letter addressed to Michizane by a Shiragi merchant, has been also written in the proposal for stopping Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China ("Kanke bunso" [an anthology of Chinese-style poetry by SUGAWARA no Michizane]) that reported to the Imperial Court by SUGAWARA no Michizane.

sen.j: 更に今日かつての平安京からは当時の唐物の代表的商品である中国製陶器が多数発掘されており、遣唐使の減少にも関わらず平安遷都以後においても中国から大量の陶器が流入しており、それらの多くは民間の商人の手によってもたらされていたと考えられている。
sen.e: Today many potteries, the flagship product of karamono (things imported from China) have been discovered from the remains of Heiankyo (平安京), and many think that although the number of the Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China declined, and even after the transfer of national capital to the city of Heiankyo, many potteries were brought from China into Japan and many of those were brought by private merchants.

Today, many potteries, the flagship product of karamono (things imported from China) that time have been excavated from the remains of Heiankyo, and many think that although the number of the Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China declined, and even after the transfer of national capital to the city of Heiankyo, many potteries were brought from China into Japan and many of those were brought by private merchants.
sen.cmt: 漢字のカッコ部分を削除しました。カンマ、that time を補いました。discovered→excavated と修正しました。
sen.e: Today, many potteries, the flagship product of karamono (things imported from China) that time have been excavated from the remains of Heiankyo, and many think that although the number of the Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China declined, and even after the transfer of national capital to the city of Heiankyo, many potteries were brought from China into Japan and many of those were brought by private merchants.

sen.j: 実際において唐など外国からの使者や商人などの来航者を乗せた船が九州に到着すると、大宰府から朝廷に報告が出され、これに対して、朝廷では大宰府に命じて来航者を博多津に置かれていた鴻臚館などの施設に引き止めて手厚く待遇した。
sen.e: When a vessel with foreigners such as envoys and merchants arrived at Kyushu, Dazaifu (local government office in Kyushu region) reported the Imperial Court about it and the Imperial Court ordered Dazaifu to stop the foreigners and treat them in facilities as Korokan at Hakatanotsu, Kyushu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対象
sen.e: When a vessel with foreigners such as envoys and merchants arrived at Kyushu, Dazaifu (local government office in Kyushu region) reported the Imperial Court about it and the Imperial Court ordered Dazaifu to stop the foreigners and give them warm welcome in the facilities such as Korokan at Hakatanotsu, Kyushu.
sen.cmt: treat them→give them warm welcome, the, such を補いました。
sen.e: When a vessel with foreigners such as envoys and merchants arrived at Kyushu, Dazaifu (local government office in Kyushu region) reported the Imperial Court about it and the Imperial Court ordered Dazaifu to stop the foreigners and give them warm welcome in the facilities such as Korokan at Hakatanotsu, Kyushu.

sen.j: その後、弁官や蔵人を唐物使に任じて寄港地に派遣し、あるいはあらかじめ朝廷から送られた希望商品の明細に基づいて大宰府の官人が直接来航者と交渉・購入する形での国家による先買権の行使を行っていた。
sen.e: The nation's right of preemption was asserted by the Imperial Court by either sending people, such as benkan (officials of the dajokan) or kurodo (Chamberlain), assigned to serve as karamono no tsukai (Supervisor of Chinese goods) to the anchorage site, or by the government officials (esp. ones of low to medium rank) directly talking to and purchasing from the marchants based on the detailed list of necessary goods made by the Imperial Court.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対象
sen.e: The nation's right of preemption was asserted by the Imperial Court by either sending people, such as benkan (officials of the dajokan) or kurodo (Chamberlain), assigned to serve as karamono no tsukai (Supervisor of Chinese goods) to the ports of call, or by the government officials (esp. ones of low to medium rank) directly negotiating and purchasing from the merchants based on the detailed list of necessary goods made by the Imperial Court.
sen.cmt: anchorage site→ports of call,marchants→merchants,talking to→negotiating と修正しました。
sen.e: The nation's right of preemption was asserted by the Imperial Court by either sending people, such as benkan (officials of the dajokan) or kurodo (Chamberlain), assigned to serve as karamono no tsukai (Supervisor of Chinese goods) to the ports of call, or by the government officials (esp. ones of low to medium rank) directly negotiating and purchasing from the merchants based on the detailed list of necessary goods made by the Imperial Court.

sen.j: にも関わらず、情報を入手した中央の貴族が家来や商人に命じて大宰府よりも先に来航者と接触して交易を行う例がしばしば見られた。
sen.e: However, aristocrats with the information about the foreign merchants often ordered their servants or related merchants to reach out them and traded with before Dazaifu.
However, those aristocrats with the information about the foreign merchants often ordered their servants or related merchants to reach out them, and traded with before Dazaifu.
sen.cmt: those, カンマを補いました。
sen.e: However, those aristocrats with the information about the foreign merchants often ordered their servants or related merchants to reach out them, and traded with before Dazaifu.

sen.j: 朝廷はこうした振る舞いを国家の先買権を犯すものとして禁令を出したが、禁令を制定する貴族が唐物に対する欲求からこうした違反行為を行った例が多かったために効果は乏しかった。
sen.e: Although the Imperial Court issued the interdict against this kind of acts that violate the nation's right of preemption, it did not have much effect on it since many of the aristocrats who enacted the interdict couldn't curb the desire for karamono and violated the interdict by themselves.

Although the Imperial Court issued the prohibition against these kinds of acts that violate the nation's right of preemption, it did not have much effect on it since many of the aristocrats who enacted the prohibition could not curb the desire for karamono, and violated the prohibition by themselves.
sen.cmt: interdict→prohibition,this kind→these kinds,couldn't→could not と修正しました。
sen.e: Although the Imperial Court issued the prohibition against these kinds of acts that violate the nation's right of preemption, it did not have much effect on it since many of the aristocrats who enacted the prohibition could not curb the desire for karamono, and violated the prohibition by themselves.

sen.j: やがて、博多津などを中心とする九州北部沿岸に唐や新羅商人による交易場が形成されるようになっていった。
sen.e: Later, trading posts were built up by the merchants from Tang and Shiragi in the northern shore area of Kyushu centering on Hakatanotsu.
Later, trading posts were built up by the merchants from Tang and Shiragi in the northern shore area of Kyushu centering on Hakatanotsu.
Later, trading posts were built up by the merchants from Tang and Shiragi in the northern shore area of Kyushu centering on Hakatanotsu.

sen.j: また、大宰府の官人など取り締まる側もこうした交易に参画するようになった。
sen.e: The regulators such as the government officials at Dazaifu also participated in this kind of trading.
The regulators such as the government officials at Dazaifu also participated in this kind of trading.
The regulators such as the government officials at Dazaifu also participated in this kind of trading.

sen.j: 例えば、張保皐と接触を持っていた筑前守文室宮田麻呂が代表的な例と言える。
sen.e: FUNYA no Miyatamaro (文室宮田麻呂), Chikuzen no kami (筑前守) (governor of Chikuzen Province), who built up contact with Jang Bogo was a major example of them.
FUNYA no Miyatamaro, Chikuzen no kami (governor of Chikuzen Province), who built up contact with Jang Bogo was a major example of them.
sen.cmt: 漢字のカッコ部分を削除しました。
sen.e: FUNYA no Miyatamaro, Chikuzen no kami (governor of Chikuzen Province), who built up contact with Jang Bogo was a major example of them.

sen.j: 遣唐使などの記録を見ると、日本より唐に対しては銀や織物、糸や布が朝貢され、唐より織物や香料、薬品、仏具、経典・書籍などが将来されたことがわかる。
sen.e: The fact that silver, textile fabrics, cloths and threads were brought to Tang Dynasty from Japan and textile fabrics, spices, medicines, Buddhist objects, scriptures and books were brought into Japan from Tang, is in records as ones written by the Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対象
sen.e: The fact that silver, textile fabrics, cloths and threads were brought to Tang Dynasty from Japan as tribute, and textile fabrics, spices, medicines, Buddhist objects, scriptures and books were brought into Japan from Tang, is seen in records as ones written by the Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China.
sen.cmt: 「朝貢され」という部分を補いました。seen を補いました。
sen.e: The fact that silver, textile fabrics, cloths and threads were brought to Tang Dynasty from Japan as tribute, and textile fabrics, spices, medicines, Buddhist objects, scriptures and books were brought into Japan from Tang, is seen in records as ones written by the Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China.

sen.j: 更にシルクロードを経由した西域の商品もあった。
sen.e: Also, there were goods from Central and Western Asia that had relayed the Silk Road.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対象
sen.e: Also, there were goods from Central and Western Asia that had relayed the Silk Road.
Also, there were goods from Central and Western Asia that had relayed the Silk Road.

sen.j: 日本への将来した唐物の一端は東大寺正倉院の宝物や『日本国見在書目録』から推定可能である。
sen.e: Some of the karamono that were brought into Japan are presumable from the treasures in Todaiji Temple Shosoin (東大寺正倉院) or "Nihonkoku genzaisho mokuroku (日本国見在書目録) (Catalogue of Present Books in Japan)."
Some of the karamono that were brought into Japan can be assumed from the treasures in Todaiji Temple Shosoin or "Nihonkoku genzaisho mokuroku" (Catalogue of Present Books in Japan).
sen.cmt: 漢字のカッコ部分を削除しました。are presumable→can be assumed,クォーツ内のカッコの位置を修正しました。
sen.e: Some of the karamono that were brought into Japan can be assumed from the treasures in Todaiji Temple Shosoin or "Nihonkoku genzaisho mokuroku" (Catalogue of Present Books in Japan).
